segments.text: July 2nd, 1976, 9 a.m. in the morning.
Interviewee, Russell R-U-S-S-E-L-L Watson, W-A-T-S-O-N, Raitt, R-A-I-T-T.
place, Scripps Institute of Oceanography, University of California.
Professor Raitt, would you first tell us when and how you first developed an interest in the sea?
Well, I think it began when I was doing wartime research at Point Loma.
during World War II when I was engaged in undersea warfare research in an attempt to do something about submarine warfare.
Then it became clear that there was very inadequate knowledge about the ocean and that some of my research ability could be useful.
Now you had earlier worked, had you not,
In the Engineering Corps?
No, not in the Engineering Corps, if you mean in the military.
No, no, I mean seismograph.
I had worked for five years doing geophysical exploration using seismic reflection technique.
And then from there, then you went on to work in war research.
What took you to war research?
I think it was...

recognition that the U.S. would be involved in the war sooner or later, and it was necessary for people with technical knowledge to come to some help in dealing with the situation, particularly the submarine.
German submarines were sinking, shipping across the Atlantic very rapidly, and if it continued very long,
that England would have been completely isolated.
So they formed a laboratory down here at Point Loma, National Defense Research Committee.
And, well, I heard about that through my connections with Caltech.
And so I joined them in the summer of 1941.
What were you doing with Caltech?
I had some indirect association with them because my work in geophysics was working with a company in which the other members of the company were also graduates of Caltech.
And I had friends there.
I had no direct association with Caltech in the sense of being on the staff or anything like that.
Did any of the work you did with the Geophysical Engineering Corps direct you towards the sea?
Yeah, that was Engineering Corporation.
Geophysical Engineering Corporation was engaged entirely in doing exploratory seismic reflection work looking for oil structures.
It had nothing to do with working the sea.
Who organized the research after you arrived at Point Loma?
Well, the director at that time was Vern Knudson, professor of physics at UCLA.
Did you propose the work you did with underwater sound and impulse waves yourself, or were they predetermined missions?
No, I was working.
I was, as all of us there were, really working on projects that were
We were working on the program of the laboratory.
The responsibility of the laboratory was to do whatever seemed most appropriate for our experience and the problems most appropriate to
to learn as rapidly as possible those things that would be useful in undersea warfare.
So I particularly was working on assigned projects, not things that I initiated myself.
Of course, the ideas of how to do it and so on came from the people that were carrying out the work.
But we generally worked on projects that were requested by the
management.
Did you notice a goodly number of people coming through this sort of work in the war to move on into the field of oceanography after the war was over?
Quite a few of them, yes, like myself, whose interest in oceanography developed through this work that they came in from other fields but continued on in oceanography.
Yes, I was not the only one.
Did you feel, or do you feel, as if the connection between oceanography and military has been beneficial for oceanography?
I think so.
Yes, and on the whole, the relationship with the military has been beneficial in a number of ways.

Did you think that perhaps in your contact with the military, let's say particularly later on, the military might have been too mission-oriented vis-a-vis, let's say, hard science in terms of projects it funded?
That's possible about some of the work, maybe.
Some of the R&D, government R&D, probably is too much mission-oriented.
My contact
is in two phases.
One is the phase where I was doing work in wartime.
The emphasis naturally was mission-oriented then, and it was only a recognition of the deficiency of knowledge about the ocean that led me to continue later.
Later, after the war, the work I've been doing is not mission-oriented at all.
It's research, fundamental research, and there's quite a difference there between the wartime work and the post-war work.
Would you comment at least upon the discovery of the deep scattering layer, speaking of pure research, how it came about, with whom you were associated?
Yes, I participated in that directly, and it came about because one of the first

assignments I had was to learn about the scattering that came out of the sea because this was directly interfering with the detection of submarines by echo ranging and this is the scattering that comes through organisms that are diffusely scattered throughout the sea not just things like whales and fish and so on that give discrete echoes give a general
scattering, which sounds very much like the reverberation that you hear in an auditorium when a sound is emitted in an auditorium, it's reflected back and forth and dies away.
The sound that you get out of the sea when you send a pulse into it sounds very much like that, so they call it reverberation.
So we were studying reverberation because it was interfering with the detection of submarines.
When we directed an extrasonic projector into the ocean,
to study the volume reverberation, we directed it vertically downwards in order to eliminate the reverberation that came out of the surface, which is separate from that that came out of volume.
As soon as we did that, we found that the scattering was not uniformly distributed throughout the scene.
Before that, everyone more or less assumed that there was something scattering there that was uniformly distributed.
As soon as we put it downward, we saw immediately that there were layers.
And that came very early in the study of reverberation out of the sea.
So that was, in a sense, a scientific discovery that was completely unexpected and a byproduct of work which was directed towards a practical study of reverberation.
You keep saying we.
With whom were you involved?
Well, I was, as everybody else working there, was involved in some sort of group activity.
And the group I worked with was led by Dr. Eyring.
There were two Eyrings.
I think his name was Carl Eyring.
He's a physicist from Utah, Brigham Young University.
The other man was Ralph Christensen.
Irene Christensen and myself were working together studying reverberation.
So this was a joint activity, not any one person was responsible for it.
Did you suspect at that time that it was caused by masses of fish and animals, or was this...?
Yes, I think there, let's see, at that time, there was a vast ignorance, and no one really knew for sure.
Even then, it wasn't certain what it came from, whether it was from organisms living in the sea or from some structure of the sea itself.
However, I think very quickly it became apparent that it wasn't the structure of the water itself, but it was the organism.
I think the fact of the deep scattering layer was the strongest single thing showing that because the scattering layer existed fairly deep in the ocean where the water structure is fairly uniform
Scattering from areas where there's more layering, like the thermocline, was much smaller.
So there were various things that indicated it was...
I think the strongest indication was biological and was that the scattering layer moved up and down diurnally.
And it came up at night and went down during the day.
And which is well known...
vertical migration of plankton and other small fish and so on.
Well, was vertical migration known at this time?
Yes.
Yes, I think Martin Johnson was the one who was most influential in pointing that out because he had studied the vertical migration of plankton by taking plankton net studies and so on.
So he was aware of this diurnal migration
of the organisms and see, and he was also at the laboratory, not at first, he wasn't there quite as early as I was, but he came later on from Scripps Institution and joined the same laboratory.
He's here now, by the way, if you want to talk to him.
Did the discovery aid your individual research?
Did this discovery of scattering layers move you more firmly into oceanography?
Perhaps, yes.
It was an exciting thing to happen and certainly it makes the field more interesting when you find that with fairly simple experiments you can make fundamental discoveries.
The joy in scientific research is making discoveries and so that
So this is kind of the motivation that led me into oceanography.
It was such a wide open field that one could go out almost any direction and discover new knowledge.
And so that was an interesting time to get into oceanography.
It's been suggested that the 1950s and early 60s were, in effect, the age of exploration as far as oceanography was concerned.
And this might now be closing off.
that, quite frankly, more oceanography may be done away from vessels and on land as oceanography becomes a more particular rather than broad field.
Would you agree with that?
Well, let's see.
I think oceanography will continue a study of the oceans by ships going out into the ocean.
The age of, let's see, the first exploration, I think,
or the age of geophysical exploration of the ocean is still continuing.
But it's past this initial phase, which is similar.
The thing that we got into, in a sense, was almost similar to the period of the 16th century exploration of the oceans that started with Europeans like Columbus and other people going out.
But the exploration is still continuing.
And new things are still being found.
And I think it'll be a long time before you can study oceans by sitting in a desk.
Some people have suggested that to be a good oceanographer, it's necessary, in effect, to get your feet wet to go out on vessels.
Do you agree with that?
Well, I don't.
I don't.
Maybe it's not.
It isn't...
Maybe it isn't necessary for every oceanographer to get his feet wet, but some of them sure do.
Otherwise, oceanography is an experimental science.
Everything that's been learned about the sea is learned by somebody going out into the ocean and observing it.
And the people, however, that have worked with data that's
made very fundamentally useful contributions to understanding the data that's taken by people that make observations.
Now, why did you and four others form the Marine Physical Lab?
Oh, that's not an absolutely simple question to answer there.
There are aspects of that that involve, let's say, the whole subject of why it was desirable to support research in oceanography.
The Marine Physical Laboratory was one
of a number of, let's say, quite a number of efforts to, let's say, to carry out this need for research in oceanography.
And it came into being through Navy support and recognition by people in the Navy that
that more fundamental research was needed in oceanography.
Marine Physical Laboratory was set up to emphasize those aspects of oceanography that are associated with the propagation of sound in the sea.
And, however, this was not, it wasn't
It wasn't oriented towards application of underwater sound, but rather to understand the fundamental properties of the ocean that were related to the propagation of underwater sound.
Understand?
And how it came, the details of how it came into being is a fairly complex story, which I don't have all of the
answers to it, although I may have remembered it at one time in the past.
But I think quite a bit of this is written up, the details of how the Marine Physical Laboratory came into being.
And the main person, of course, involved in that and would not have come into being if he hadn't taken a very
active and aggressive role, and that was Carl Eckert.
And he was the important person in the Marine Physical Laboratory.
And I was one of the people that was fortunate enough to become associated with him in the formation of the laboratory.
How did you meet Carl Eckert?
And I met him first in this wartime laboratory, which I mentioned right at the beginning of the interview.
I met him very shortly after I joined
there in the summer of 1941.
He came from the University of Chicago.
And then after, would you agree with this, as the war is winding down, it becomes apparent that more pure research has to be done in the sea, and from this, then, the marine physical lab evolves?
That was it.
It was a strong feeling of

a number of people, both in the academic world and in the Navy, that the research that really began during the war should be continued, particularly in those fields which had been opened up during the war but on which no work really could be done because the emphasis had the necessity to be placed during the war
on the application of knowledge rather than on the acquisition of knowledge.
The Marine Physical Laboratory, was it funded by the Office of Naval Research?
There was no Office of Naval Research at the time Marine Physical Laboratory was formed.
So the funds initially came from the Bureau of Ships.
Now, what types of information about the bottom were you able to gather as a result of techniques you developed with sound transmissions?
Well, let's see.
All of our knowledge, I think, of the ocean bottom is gained through that kind of technique, this use of underwater sound.
All of the information comes by studying the reflection of sound.
from the sea bottom or from layers underneath the sea bottom, or by propagation through the sea bottom that we call refraction.
So basically there are two fields here of study, one called the reflection of sound, the other refraction of sound.

This is, I think, what shows the association between the knowledge of the sea floor, the structure of the sea floor, and the propagation of sand is that we learn a good deal about the nature of the sea bottom by studying the underwater sand at the same time
one gains a good deal of knowledge about how sound is propagated by learning about what flies beneath the sea floor.
It's a very important part of the whole problem.
When did you come to Scripps?
Well, the transition to Scripps was a gradual one.
I started at the end of the war in the Marine Physical Laboratory,
was a branch then, or in a sense, a division or a laboratory of the University of California, separate from Scripps Institution.
As time went on, the relation with Scripps Institution became stronger and stronger.
And then I believe, I can't remember the exact date, probably in 49,
I got an appointment as associate professor at Scripps Institution.
But my association with Scripps began before that, although I wasn't really part of the academic staff or faculty at Scripps.
I was still associated with them.
I believe I taught a course here in Underwater Sound before I was out.
on the faculty.
So the transition was not a dramatic, abrupt one, but a gradual one.
What happened to the Marine Physical Laboratory when you came to Scripps?
Well, it continues and still is in existence.
And because of my residents here on the campus and other people from Marine Physical Laboratory,
a branch, essentially, of Marine Physical Laboratory here on the campus, as well as a continuing activity down at Point Loma.
Well, so then you make a transition then from the Marine Physical Laboratory to be finally full-time at Scripps.
But I'm still part of the Marine Physical Laboratory at

even though I'm a member of Scripps on the faculty, the research I've been conducting through the Marine Physical Laboratory, which is a research division, in a sense, of Scripps Institutional Oceanography.
Now, had you always been interested in teaching, or did the teaching at Scripps
develop, let's say, in addition to research?
My teaching is really research.
I teach whatever effectiveness I have, and teaching is owing to maybe graduate students learning how to do research for me.
I'm not a teacher in the sense of lecturing to students, but rather one in which helping them with research problems.
Now, when you came to Scripps, how large was the faculty here?
Do you remember?
That would be hard for me to say.
I think you'd better look that up.
It would be, of course, much smaller than it is now.
Well, it'll roughly quadruple while you're here.
And as it quadruples, what happens in terms of sound transmission, working seismology?
Does it do it?
Do you seem to give direction to that part of the extension of the faculty?
The whole field has changed.
And let's say my own involvement in what I call seismic methods of study came from the, let's say,
from the sound aspect.
However, that's not generally true.
And most people getting into this field do it the other way, from being directly interested in seismic work and then applying that to the ocean.
So let's say there is a seismology involved here on the campus, for example.
and of a more, you might say, more of a classical seismology.
Professor Bruhn, for example, is a leading member of that field.
He's been president of the Seismological Society of America.
And there are other people at the Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics, IGPP, who are worldwide
prominent in this field of seismology, which is really dry land seismology in a sense, but it's evolved from the land, but it's also getting more involved into the ocean.
So there's this approach from really two different directions, from the idea of sound propagation, one hand, and the other, you might call it continental seismology, earthquake seismology, and so on.
It's that earthquake seismology is moving into the ocean.
That's one of the current developments, very active.
And I think some of the leading work is being done right here at Scripps Institution, up at the IGPP, in that they're putting instruments out on the bottom now.
Instead of just having them on dry land, they're putting seismographs.
On the bottom, study earthquakes.
